text: the aftermath of a tragedy Saudis civil
defense workers treated hundreds of
injured pilgrims near Mecca today as the
death toll from a stampede rose steadily
it took place that Mina has up to 2
million Muslims converged for the climax
of the annual Hajj pilgrimage one of the
five pillars of faith in Islam the crush
happened despite massive precautions
taken and billions of dollars spent on
improving infrastructure it's the worst
tragedy to hit the Hajj in 25 years this
is the most important place for us as
Muslims it's every Muslims dream to be
here
so to get this news just few weeks after
the crane accident it's heartbreaking
you don't know if one of them is going
to be your friend or your family member
even if it's no one you know it it's bad
enough only this month Saudi Arabia
suffered a horrific accident when a
crane collapsed on two worshippers at
the Grand Mosque in Mecca during a storm
over a hundred people were killed
prompting an investigation into safety
standards some of the worst Hajj
incidents include a 1990s stampede in a
tunnel that killed over 1,400 pilgrims
in 2004 244 pilgrims were killed in a
crush at the tent city of Mena and then
in 2006 more than 360 pilgrims were
killed in a stampede also at Mena
those earlier incidents prompted the
site is to spend billions of dollars on
improving safety and security for the
two million pilgrims who arrive each
year around a hundred thousand security
officers were deployed this year along
with helicopters hundreds of ambulances
and a vast array of surveillance cameras
and yet still it seems this failed to
prevent disaster there's a lot been done
in as far as infrastructure has been
concerned however we need to understand
what's going on today
and and understand how they can be
improved so that you know further
casualties don't take place or further
incidents don't take place Saudi Arabia
and those who've come to make this
sacred pilgrimage have been left in
shock by today's tragedy now the
authorities will have to look once again
at what more can be done to prevent such
a disaster Frank Gardner BBC News
